description: From Middle English forgrowen, from Old English forgrōwan (“to grow up, grow into, increase, overgrow”), equivalent to for- +‎ grow.

verbs.description: forgrow (third-person singular simple present forgrows, present participle forgrowing, simple past forgrew, past participle forgrown)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, obsolete) To grow to excess or out of shape; grow unduly.
examples: A terror to the new made folke, which neuer erst had knowne
So foule a Dragon in their life, so monstrously foregrowne,
So great a ground thy poyson paunch did vnderneath thée hide.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, obsolete) To become grown over; overgrow; become covered with growth (usually one that is excessive or unsightly).
examples: And at the last a path of litle breade
I found, that greatly had not used be,
For it forgrowen was with grasse and weede
That well unneth a wight might it se.
